description: Cap up to 35 cm across, initially white then discoloring brownish with dark fibrils. Firm stem up to 15 cm long with ring. White spore print. DISTINCTIVE cinnamon-spicy aroma is critical identifier, stem base always shows fine gritty sand from soil.
habitat: Forms mycorrhiza with pine species in sandy spodosol/podzol soil. Found concealed under litter in dry pine forests (sugar pine, ponderosa, lodgepole) on Pacific coast.
season: Pacific Northwest: October-January (especially West Coast), General: Late summer to early winter in cool, damp weather.
lookalikes: Amanita smithiana (Smith's Amanita) - CAUSES KIDNEY FAILURE - torpedo-shaped stem, breaks easily, mild odor (lacks cinnamon scent), 2-3 mushrooms can cause kidney failure requiring dialysis
safety_notes: NOT a beginner mushroom due to deadly lookalikes. MUST verify strong cinnamon/spicy aroma (Amanita smithiana lacks this). Stem must be firm and solid (Amanita breaks easily). Can grow immediately next to deadly Amanita smithiana in same habitat.
